bibl.title: [Letter] 1831 Jan. 17, [to] James Moore King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Shubal S. King
bibl.author: Shubal S. King
bibl.note: Letter dated January 17, 1831 from Shubal S. King to James M. King. The letter primarily concerns financial transactions, and cotton prices in different states

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 3.0 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.opener:
Mc Kinley AlaJaney 21 Col. Jas. M. KingMurfrees boroughTennessee Shubal King 1840 or 1846 To Mail1831
McKinley January the 17th Col. James M. King
div1.p: The object of this short epistle , is to inform you that , James Snell left here on yesterday morning for , Tennessee , I gave him nignty one dollars in specie for, you the remainder in South carolina money, which I resund is current in your state —

I regret that I have not had an oppertunity of sending it before this time, but it was totally out of my power, as no opportunity presented itself — before Snell came down— I have no knews of any interest, or importance to communicate— The times here, are verry hard and, but little money — Cotton is selling for nuthing of consiquence, the Milileu prices are form five to seven sents &c— Father speaks of going to Orleans with his, and selling it, for sound funds if so, his will go up the misisipie, for the purpus of exchangeing the proseeds for our own currency, and, as soon you get this, pleas write to immediately, and state the difference of exchange in your part of the country

Since I arrived at home I have employed my time primairaly in hunting deer the weak after my arrival here there was a company of us went out , and hunted five days during the time , we killed eighteen , I only killed one of them myself, But since the present year set in I have been closely engaged at my books Tell Rufus I have been anxiouly expecting a letter from him , but in which I have been sadly mistaken, Tell him John and Mr. Gannaway, and Mr. Jamison to write to me as, I trust, the short term that , I have been absent
from there has not entirely abated or, obliterated the frindship that formily existed betwean me and them I have nothing more to write give my love Cousine Patsy and and respects to all enquiring friends
div1.closer:
Your friend and relation Shubal S. KingJ M King —
P. S. If I have not sent you the compliment of money let me know when you write , and probably I will have an opportunity of sending it by some one passing up your way —
I think it is probably I may go up that way next fall myself s.s. King
